generated_text: The structure of hydrate is of great importance for understanding the formation mechanism of hydrate and its stability. However, the structure of hydrate is still controversial. In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate at high pressure and temperature. The results provide a new insight into the structure of hydrate and the mechanism of hydrate formation. This work also provides a new method to study the structure of hydrate at high pressure and temperature.

We provide a categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The approach is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. It is based on a small number of axioms that are shown to be sufficient to guarantee that the category of Hilbert spaces and normal, linear operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. The approach is thus a step toward a mathematical foundation for quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive structure, the polar capsule, is unknown. Here, we report the genomes of two distantly related myxozoans, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare them to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals and that the parasite has lost many genes involved in development and cell–cell communication. These findings suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. This is consistent with the hypothesis that the myxozoan transition to parasitism was accompanied by a major evolutionary event in the history of animal evolution. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that the accessory protein Orf6 of SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated factors (ISFs) and thereby impair the antiviral transcriptional response. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain. This interaction is required for the viral antagonism of IFN. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the viral antagonism of IFN and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050. To feed this population, the global food production will have to increase by 70% by 2050. However, the optimum growing temperature for maize is 27 °C, and the mean temperature is expected to increase by 2 °C to 4 °C by 2050. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability to quantify how maize yields will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savannas. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of species-level identification of plant remains in traditional studies. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of LMH in the maintenance of biodiversity in African savannas. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses are planning to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, its global distribution and fate in the ocean are still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris in the ocean interior. These sinks are likely to be related to the fast nano-fragmentation of the plastic debris into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. The global distribution of floating plastic debris is mostly related to the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. This distribution is a consequence of the global distribution of the plastic sources.

The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is one of the most important questions in presolar grain research. We determined the ages of 40 large SiC grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that a majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This result has implications for the origin of presolar grains in general. It is important to understand the formation process of large presolar grains in the interstellar medium. This is a key step to understand the formation of the Solar System.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased exponentially. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could increase by 1 million more motorized vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of all forms of care. Here, we show that the evolution of domestication and all forms of allocare are associated with increased reproductive output. We also show that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This finding has implications for the evolution of care and the evolution of humans. We suggest that the evolution of human care may be driven by the need to increase the metabolic power of the mother. This may have been a key factor in the evolution of the human species. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. No treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. VX-765 was able to reduce truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. However, further studies are needed to confirm these results in a larger animal model and in patients. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the most numerous cell type in the body and is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system. The endothelium is able to control many of the most important physiological processes, including blood pressure, inflammation, and the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between the blood and tissues. The endothelium is able to integrate information from multiple sources and coordinate its responses. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected in a network, and that the network is organized in a way that allows for rapid and robust communication between cells. The network is also organized in a way that allows for the efficient transmission of information between cells. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms that control the endothelium and its role in the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In response, we have developed a suite of data products that provide open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. These data are available through an API and accompanying software packages. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are relevant to tracking the pandemic, and to augmenting traditional public health reporting. The data are also relevant to a wide range of research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selectivity of the channel for K+ ions. The selectivity filter is also the site of allosteric communication between the activation and inactivation gates. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the allosteric communication and that its substitution with Alanine leads to a lack of C-type inactivation gating. Finally, we have shown that the selectivity filter can be collapsed by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural explanation for the allosteric communication between the activation and inactivation gates. It also provides a structural basis for the collapse of the selectivity filter. This work is expected to contribute to the development of potassium channel blockers and activators. It is also expected to contribute to the development of potassium channel-based therapies.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for the health of the host. The role of the anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi. These fungi are a previously uncharacterized group of microbes that are likely to be important players in the gut microbiome. The discovery of these natural products could lead to the development of new therapeutics and antibiotics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. However, the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety is mediated by the nucleus accumbens and is dependent on mitochondrial function. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and the design of complex structures are often limited by the restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we use a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures. The structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to design and manufacture mechanical structures with desired behaviors. It is expected to inspire the design of mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern is regulated by the transcription factors BCL11A and GATA2. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is silenced in the adult bone marrow. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 is expressed at high levels and can reverse the adult hemoglobin expression pattern. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This knowledge may be useful for the development of therapeutic strategies for hemoglobinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) function, highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. This resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. Genetic or pharmacologic ablation of SREBP1 or SCD1 sensitized ferroptosis in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The underlying mechanisms of hypertension-induced heart failure are complex and not fully understood. Here, we show that the major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) activate STIM1, which in turn activates ORAI channels. This process promotes vascular remodeling and may contribute to the development of heart failure in patients with hypertension. Our findings may help to explain the association of LCCBs with heart failure and may lead to the development of new strategies to reduce the risk of heart failure in patients with hypertension.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal lands. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations in early-seral ecosystems, but that the policy failed to halt the decline of older forests. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and the need to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is therefore essential. In this study, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the membrane permeability, binding affinity to the ribosome, and solubility of the designed compounds. We show that the designed compounds are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens and that the best compound is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin. The approach can be used to design new antibiotics against other pathogens. The compounds designed by us are currently being tested in vivo. The results of these studies will be published in the near future.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of trainable parameters, and is able to adapt to different problems automatically. The proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several segmentation problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). Over the Quaternary, we observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices, such as tablets and smartphones, within 1 h of bedtime has become increasingly common. This study shows that this practice has a negative impact on sleep. Participants who read an electronic book on a light-emitting device took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an electronic device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. This study also highlights the need for more research on the effects of light on the circadian system and the need for more stringent regulations on the use of electronic devices before bedtime. The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth’s history. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results provide evidence for the YDB cooling being triggered by an impact. (Show more)

The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmunity is controversial. Here, we show that the early death of CTLA-4 knockout mice is not due to the absence of autoimmunity, but rather to the development of a spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. This was not fatal, but led to a severe disease phenotype. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells, but T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is a central regulator of immune responses and its function is not restricted to the periphery. This study provides a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. It also provides a model for the study of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. We found that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. These results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. This study provides insights into the evolution of beetles and their impact on the evolution of plants and the environment. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE. In fact, the greater variation participants had access to in the larger populations may have overwhelmed their working memory and weakened their ability to selectively copy the best-adapted plane(s). We conclude that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the development of human societies. They also have implications for the design of experiments and the interpretation of results in the social sciences. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 2,300 km. It is the densest part of the Earth. The inner core is a mystery because it is difficult to understand how it formed. In this study, we found that the inner core may have formed by a two-step process. First, the inner core formed by the bcc phase of iron. Second, the bcc phase transformed into the hcp phase. This mechanism explains the inner core nucleation paradox. It also provides a clue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. This study may help us to understand the formation of the inner core and the Earth. It may also help us to understand the origin of the Earth.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less understood. Here, we show that marijuana abusers have reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity to MP in marijuana abusers might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. The findings also highlight the need to investigate the effects of marijuana on the brain in the context of chronic use.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also the most complex cognitive skill we have. How the human brain processes language is therefore a central question in cognitive neuroscience. Here, we use a state-of-the-art approach to link brain and behavior across many datasets and many computational models to reveal the neural and computational mechanisms of language comprehension. We find that predictive processing, the core mechanism of deep learning, is also critical for language comprehension in the human brain. These results provide computational evidence for predictive processing as a fundamental mechanism of language comprehension in the brain. They also provide a blueprint for future studies linking brain and language models to the study of language evolution and development.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still unclear whether the success of DL is due to its ability to find good solutions or its ability to find good solutions in a stable way. In this paper, we show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This result implies a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the success of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the failure of science communication. The pandemic is often described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper is about one of the factors, a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. It is about how the experiment’s critical design flaws were overlooked, and how the study became a canonical example of a phenomenon it was set out to study. It is about the cognitive bias of overinterpreting evidence, and the need to be more skeptical of the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. In this study, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, an uncultured human pathogen associated with diffuse lepromatous leprosy and a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. The two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. The ancient separation of the two leprosy bacilli is also reflected in their evolutionary history, which is characterized by a high rate of pseudogenization.

Entanglement and entropy are central concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also fundamental to the understanding of thermodynamics. However, the evolution of entanglement and entropy in time is not trivial, and it is only recently that a complete understanding of the evolution of entanglement in terms of quasiparticles was achieved. Here, we show that this result can be extended to the case of interacting systems. We also provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. Our results are exact and valid for any integrable model.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus, which is associated with severe adverse effects. To address this, we developed a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. The vaccine is temperature sensitive, which allows for the use of a single intranasal dose. The vaccine is highly attenuated, resulting in a mild disease in hamsters. The vaccine is able to protect hamsters from the lethal challenge of the wild-type virus. The vaccine is easy to manufacture and can be stored at 2–8 °C. These properties make the vaccine suitable for mass vaccination programs.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It has been responsible for the deaths of millions of people in the past and continues to be a threat to human health today. In this study, we use a mathematical model to investigate the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of plague during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). Our results suggest that human fleas and lice were primary vectors for plague during this period, challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the history of plague and the development of vector control strategies to prevent future outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic of interest to many researchers. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is still poorly understood. We present a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of brain neuronal density across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This study provides a more accurate picture of the evolution of brain neuronal density and its relationship with brain size. It also has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the function of TRAP1 in normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Thus, TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Actin filaments are the main components of the cytoskeleton, which is responsible for maintaining the shape of the cell. They are also the main components of many cellular processes, such as cell migration and cell division. In these processes, the filaments are often connected to each other, and they are under mechanical stress. We show that the proteins of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family are the central regulators of actin filament disassembly. We show that they do so by severing the filaments. We show that the severing is enhanced by a mechanical torque that is induced by the proteins upon binding to the filaments. This mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We believe that it is a general mechanism that is used by many proteins to enhance their ability to sever their substrates.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for the development of obesity and suggest that fructose may be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its history. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian language family is spoken. The island is also a hotspot of endemism, with 45% of its species being endemic. The settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its history. The settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its history.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which is well established in laboratory experiments. However, the results of previous experiments are controversial. We show that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to the short-term, and that it can last for years. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. Our results have implications for the design of social media platforms, and for the study of emotional contagion in the real world.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of protein in all cells. The addition of a single nucleotide to the mRNA sequence can change the rate of protein synthesis. In this study, we show that the presence of a single nucleotide modification in the mRNA sequence can change the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of this modification can change the rate of protein synthesis.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and they are not driven by factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of aquatic mammals is a classic example of the evolution of form to function. Here, we use a quantitative approach to test the relative importance of different hypothesized drivers of the evolution of aquatic mammals. We find that the evolution of aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and that the evolution of aquatic mammals is constrained by the aquatic environment.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. Rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanism is used to regulate the expression of virulence factors and biofilm formation. The type IV pili are extended and retracted, and this activity is sensed by the chemosensory system PilJ. This system is similar to the chemotaxis system, and it uses the mechanical activity of the pili to regulate the production of cAMP, which in turn regulates the expression of virulence factors. This is a unique mechanism that uses pili as a sensor and as a regulator of surface attachment. This mechanism is important for understanding the complex interactions between bacteria and their environment. It also provides a mechanism for bacteria to sense the mechanical activity of their own appendages. This mechanism may be important for understanding the role of pili in bacterial motility and biofilm formation. It may also provide a mechanism for bacteria to sense their own mechanical activity. This mechanism may be important for understanding the role of pili in bacterial motility and biofilm formation. It may also provide a mechanism for bacteria to sense their own mechanical activity.

The global use of pesticides in agriculture is increasing, and the use of newer-generation insecticides is on the rise. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the exposure of surface waters to these insecticides. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and society. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the blood of free-living deer. We also show that deer can transmit the virus to each other. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global health crisis. The disease is believed to be driven by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are toxic to neurons. However, we show that the intraneuronal burden of Aβ is a significant driver of the disease, since Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of inflammation. This finding has implications for the development of future AD therapies, since targeting the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a more effective strategy than targeting the Aβ plaques. This work also provides a potential explanation for the failure of many AD treatments to prevent or slow disease progression. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a critical therapeutic target for AD. © 2022, The Author(s).

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which demonstrates that the exploitation of chickens was widespread in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method to study the folding of a large protein in high structural detail. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein of 370 residues. We find that the folding of the protein is a multistep process.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to RNA caps. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap of Np4-capped RNAs is also able to remove the cap of other capped RNAs. This enzyme, which is normally inactivated by stress, is able to recognize capped RNAs by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. This enzyme is also able to remove capped RNAs at a much higher rate than other capped RNAs, suggesting that it may play a role in the rapid degradation of those RNAs during stress. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which bacteria regulate gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression associated with sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, could be a potential therapeutic target to restore immune function. We demonstrated that citrulline, a nonproteinogenic amino acid, could increase arginine plasma levels and restore T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing the expansion of Treg and MDSCs in a mouse model of sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a potential therapeutic target to improve the outcome of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of the biosphere is concentrated in a few taxa, including plants, animals, and bacteria. We also show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis highlights the importance of the historical impact of humans on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are also relevant for understanding the origin and evolution of life on Earth. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems with no external control parameter reach a critical state. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, including quantum devices. However, it is brittle and has a narrow bandgap. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain. This opens up opportunities to tailor its properties for applications.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is not well understood. Here, we report the structure and antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula. The structure of the peptide is largely disordered and dynamic. It exhibits potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. It binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and induces reactive oxygen species in germlings of the fungal pathogen Botrytis cinerea. The peptide can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide to control plant fungal diseases. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides and opens up the possibility of developing this class of peptides as a spray-on fungicide. The male–female reproductive axis is a classic example of a system in which the contributions of the sexes are intertwined. However, the extent to which the female contributes to the sperm proteome is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is modified after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female contributes to the proteome of sperm during the period between mating and fertilization. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a model for understanding the molecular hand-off between males and females during the reproductive process. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is critical for the coagulation and hemostasis pathways. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that VWD mutations can be explained by a mechanism of conformational regulation. We also show that the mechanism of regulation is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has been largely ignored. This study is a first step toward a comprehensive understanding of the human virome. We find that the human body is a reservoir for over 45,000 unique viruses, and that many of these viruses are associated with disease. This study is a first step toward a comprehensive understanding of the human virome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL can simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to contribute to the understanding of ACI. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The HSRL is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth. In this study, we use the thermostability of ancestral enzymes to determine the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the mechanism of K+ channel gating and C-type inactivation. They also provide a basis for the development of new K+ channel blockers and activators. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 245 million cases and 438,000 deaths in 2019. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and suggests that the parasite and host cell are in a dynamic equilibrium, with parasite and host cell forces working together to facilitate invasion. This study has implications for the development of new antimalarial therapies. (Show more)

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, including quantum devices. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be made a conductor by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be made a semiconductor by applying pressure. These findings can be used to tailor the properties of diamond for many applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity condition are more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that humidity may be a potential target for influenza vaccine design and antiviral therapy. Copyright © 2022, American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of the sentence as a whole, from the beginning to the end. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this claim is still missing. Here, we show that the brain activity in the left hemisphere increases with each successive word in a sentence, and decreases when words are merged into phrases. This merge operation is consistent with the idea of a parser that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is a first step toward understanding the neural basis of language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in development and homeostasis. It is important for the regulation of cell fate and cell proliferation. Axin is a key component of the pathway. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin are similar in their function, but they are regulated differently. This differential regulation may be important for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the LH. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity, a major health problem in the United States and worldwide.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would allow for the delivery of biologically fixed nitrogen (N2) to the plant, which is more efficient and less expensive than the current synthetic methods. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to develop a sustainable nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in agriculture. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest. It is also one of the most threatened. In this paper, we study the impact of a program that facilitated the transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to perceive the world around them. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in anatomy and morphology, but all are part of the animal’s body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global health issues. We estimate the health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel and the reduction of other anthropogenic sources of air pollution. We find that a phaseout of fossil fuels can save 3.61 million lives per year, and a reduction of all anthropogenic sources can save 5.55 million lives per year. The phaseout of fossil fuels and the reduction of other anthropogenic sources can also restore the aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns in many regions of the world. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and the reduction of other anthropogenic sources of air pollution is needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 vaccines are needed worldwide to contain the pandemic. The currently approved vaccines are effective, but their prices may limit their global access. We report a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that can be expressed in bacteria at high yield and can be used to design a virus-like particle (VLP) vaccine. The VLP vaccine can be produced at a large scale and is expected to be affordable. The VLP vaccine can be used to protect against variants of concern. This work provides a platform for the development of vaccines against other pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the underlying molecular mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we report the identification of secreted ALKAL proteins as ligands for human ALK and the related leukocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK). We show that these ligands are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish and Drosophila melanogaster. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in neural crest development and suggest a role of ALKALs in the pathogenesis of neuroblastoma. This study provides a molecular basis for the involvement of ALKALs in neural crest development and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma. The history of plague is one of the most dramatic in the history of life on Earth. The pathogen Yersinia pestis has caused devastating outbreaks throughout human history, and it is thought to have emerged from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which is a critical period of development for pathogens. Our results suggest that Y. pestis was not a single lineage during this period, but rather a single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification. This is in contrast to other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available, which show rapid diversification during this period. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of Y. pestis. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, hegemonic masculinity predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for the study of gender, race, and class in the United States. (PsycInfo Database Record

The management of agricultural lands has a major impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to a loss of soil carbon. However, the management of agricultural lands can also increase soil carbon. Here, we show that the management of agricultural lands can increase soil carbon, and that this increase can be maintained over time. We also show that the management of agricultural lands can increase soil carbon, and that this increase can be maintained over time. These results highlight the potential of agricultural lands to mitigate climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a global system to identify and prioritize viruses with the potential to spillover and spread in humans. We used a combination of expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. The tool can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. In some species, the color of the nectar is red, which is thought to be an adaptation to attract pollinators. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular basis for the study of the evolution of nectar chemistry. (Show more)

The history of Europe is marked by a series of migrations and invasions, which have shaped the modern European population. However, the processes that led to the current genetic structure are not fully understood. Here we present a case study of a group of women who were deformed by cranial cranial deformation. We show that they had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we show that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. We used metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate the regional pathogen landscape and surveillance of emerging pathogens in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. Early detection of chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce Southeast Asia is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied in other resource-scarce settings to better understand the regional pathogen landscape and surveillance of emerging pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. The human cell is constantly replicating its genome. This process is integral to life and requires the faithful duplication of DNA. The lagging strand of the DNA double helix is replicated by the polymerase δ (pol δ) holoenzyme, which is responsible for the faithful replication of every nucleobase. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we show that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for the replication of the human genome. This article is protected by copyright. The origin of life is one of the most important questions in science. In this paper, we report the first demonstration of the ability of RNA to replicate itself. This is a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

Urban change is a complex process that is difficult to study. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study other urban processes, such as gentrification and urban decay. It can also be used to study the physical changes in other types of environments, such as shopping malls and office parks. Our method can be extended to measure changes in the physical appearances of other types of environments, such as shopping malls and office parks. COVID-19 is a severe pneumonia caused by the novel coronavirus. The clinical manifestations are diverse, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment is mainly supportive. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the interleukin-6 pathway, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a highly toxic metal. The maintenance of sufficient but nontoxic pools of copper is accomplished through diverse homeostasis mechanisms in fungi. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and have significant metal-dependent antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings have implications for the role of copper in fungal biology and for the development of antifungal therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is consistent with the high temperatures (>870 °C) and pressures (>100 kbar) required for its formation. The tridymite is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals and the amorphous silica, and is possibly derived from silicic volcanism. The amorphous silica is cogenetic with the other primary and secondary minerals and is possibly derived from multiple aqueous solutions. The presence of the tridymite, amorphous silica, and other primary and secondary minerals in a Martian mudstone is consistent with the formation of the mudstone in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment.

Frost events are a major cause of crop and forest losses, and their frequency is increasing in the context of climate change. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the evolutionary history of temperate and boreal trees. We also show that the future evolution of frost damage in forests depends on the region. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing frost risk.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, Th17 cells display substantial developmental plasticity, such that some progeny of Th17 cell precursors retain a predominantly IL-17A+ phenotype, whereas others extinguish IL-17 expression and acquire expression of IFN-γ, giving rise to “Th1-like” cells. It remains unclear what role these subsets play in inflammatory bowel disease. Here, we show that IFN-γ–deficient Th17 cells are unable to induce colitis in recipients, indicating that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis. Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells and are able to directly transition to Th1-like cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms. Understanding the mechanisms underlying these two modes of action may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is poorly understood. We report a method to rapidly convert adult human fibroblasts into induced astrocytes (i-astrocytes) from ALS patients. These cells are toxic to motor neurons, and this toxicity is dependent on the ALS-causing mutation. This method now enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify therapies for ALS. This approach may also be applicable to other neurodegenerative diseases. The gut microbiota of arthropods is an important component of their immune system and plays a role in the transmission of infectious agents. Here, we show that the tick-borne bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of the bacterium to colonize the vector. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the bacterial peptidoglycan cell wall, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. They also suggest that targeting the gut microbiota may be a promising strategy for controlling vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

Birds are one of the most successful animal groups on Earth. However, the origin of the modern avian bauplan is still a matter of debate. Here, we report the discovery of a new basal member of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”). This new taxon, named Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the origin of the modern avian bauplan. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.
